questions.question: What is the cancellation policy?
questions.expected_answer: Patients must provide at least 24 hours notice to cancel without penalty. Cancellations with less than 24 hours notice are considered late cancellations.

questions.question: What happens if I cancel less than 12 hours before my appointment?
questions.expected_answer: Cancellations made less than 12 hours before the appointment may be recorded as a no-show equivalent.

questions.question: What is considered a no-show?
questions.expected_answer: A no-show occurs when a patient fails to arrive for their scheduled appointment, arrives more than 15 minutes late without prior notice, or does not cancel or reschedule before the appointment time.

questions.question: What are the consequences of multiple no-shows?
questions.expected_answer: First no-show: verbal reminder. Second no-show: written warning letter. Third no-show: $75 fee and pre-payment required. Fourth no-show: review by patient relations, possible discharge.

questions.question: Can no-show fees be waived?
questions.expected_answer: Yes, exceptions may be made for medical emergencies, hospitalization, death in immediate family, severe weather emergencies, or transportation emergencies with documentation. Patients may appeal within 14 days.

questions.question: When are appointment reminders sent?
questions.expected_answer: Reminders are sent at: 7 days before (email), 48 hours before (SMS), 24 hours before (SMS with confirmation request), and 2 hours before (final SMS).

questions.question: What interventions are used for high-risk patients?
questions.expected_answer: High-risk patients receive phone calls at 72 hours before, enhanced SMS reminders, transportation assistance offers, barrier assessment, and waitlist backup scheduling.
